title: When Unions Sit on Both Sides of the Table
sub_head: Collective bargaining for the public sector was a big mistake.
body:
In “The High Cost of Not Being Wisconsin” (Cross Country, April 6) Carol Platt Liebau writes, “Connecticut taxpayers have good reason to wonder where racing in the opposite direction [of Wisconsin] will take them.” Connecticut taxpayers have better reason to wonder why they have no representation at the negotiating table when the public unions make their extraordinary demands.
In business, executives and board members are required to recuse themselves from decisions in which they have a financial interest that potentially conflicts with shareholder interests. With our state and federal officials, almost universally members of the Democratic Party, we have a vicious circle of union election funding followed by their beneficiaries cutting the unions sweetheart deals across the table.
